raw_text:
Double injury blow strikes Wales
 
 Wales centre Sonny Parker and number eight Ryan Jones will miss Saturday's game with Italy because of injury.
 
 Parker has not recovered from a trapped nerve in his neck that kept him out of the win over England, and Tom Shanklin is expected to continue at centre. Jones damaged his collar bone after coming on as a replacement against England and joins flanker Colin Charvis (foot injury) on the sidelines. Meanwhile, Mike Ruddock may make Gavin Henson his first-choice kicker in Rome. The centre was Wales' hero in the 11-9 Six Nations win over England, landing a huge late penalty from wide out to clinch the game. First-choice kicker Stephen Jones handed over responsibility because of Henson's greater kicking range, but the fly-half had already missed a number of shots at goal. "Our first aim was to get Gavin settled into the team, but giving him the kicks is something we'll talk about in selection this week," Wales coach Mike Ruddock told BBC Sport Wales. Henson himself says he is relishing all the media hype that has been heaped on him since last Saturday's game. "I thrive on it and think it makes me perform better," he said. "I'm glad it's a short week before the Italy game. There was so much build-up before England, but we fly out to Rome on Thursday and we'll be back playing again."
llama3.2:1b: Wales' Sonny Parker and Ryan Jones will miss Wales' Six Nations match against Italy due to injury, with Tom Shanklin set to continue at centre. Colin Charvis has been injured as well. Mike Ruddock may make Gavin Henson his first-choice kicker instead of Stephen Jones after Jones missed a number of shots.

qwen2.5:3b: Wales centre Sonny Parker and number eight Ryan Jones will miss their upcoming match against Italy due to injury. Parker is recovering from a neck issue while Jones injured his collarbone in the last game against England. This leaves flanker Colin Charvis and centre Tom Shanklin as replacements. Coach Mike Ruddock may consider giving first-choice kicker Stephen Jones duties, potentially making Wales' new star kicker Gavin Henson start. Henson welcomes the attention but is aware of the short week ahead before facing Italy.
opencoder:1.5b: The double injury blow strike in Wales resulted in a win over Italy, but Ryan Jones missed Saturday's match due to injuries from the injury blow strike. The injury blow strike was not directly caused by Parker's nerve trap. He joined the England team with a foot injury and Col Charvis replaced England on the sidelines. Shanklin was expected to continue at centre while Jones suffered from damage to the collar bone which was a replacement against England. The game also ended up losing to Rome, with Gavin Henson leading with a greater kicking range than Stephen Jones and it has not been given away for lack of further shots. As for Mike Ruddock's decision, Gavin is expected to be his first-choice kicker in Rome as per the text.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should preserve key ideas and details from the original text:

Wales centre Sonny Parker and number eight Ryan Jones will miss Saturday's game with Italy because of injury.

The injury is a trapped nerve in Parker's neck that kept him out of the win over England, and Tom Shanklin is expected to continue at centre. Jones damaged his collar bone after coming on as a replacement against England and joins flanker Colin Charvis (foot injury) on the sidelines. Meanwhile, Mike Ruddock may make Gavin Henson his first-choice kicker in Rome. The centre was Wales' hero in the 11-9 Six Nations win over England, landing a huge late penalty from wide out to clinch the game. First-choice kicker Stephen Jones handed over responsibility because of Henson's greater kicking range, but the fly-half had already missed a number of shots at goal. "Our first aim was to get Gavin settled into the team, but giving him the kicks is something we'll talk about in selection this week," Wales coach Mike Ruddock told BBC Sport Wales. Henson himself says he is relishing all the media hype that has been heaped on him since last Saturday's game. "I thrive on it and think it makes me perform better," he said. "I'm grateful to have played for Wales, but I'm also grateful to be back in Italy."

<think>
Okay, I need to help the user by summarizing this text. Let's read through it carefully.

The first sentence says that Wales have two key injuries: Sonny Parker and Ryan Jones. Both are missing because of injury. 

Parker isn't fully recovered from a neck injury that stopped him from winning against England. He expects Tom Shanklin to stay at center as he played for England. 

Jones had a collard bone issue when he came on for England, so he joined Colin Charvis on the bench and is now in flanker.

Mike Ruddock is mentioned as possibly making Gavin Henson his first-choice kicker because of his bigger range, but Henson hasn't kicked any shots yet. He's relishing all the media attention after last Saturday's game, especially before Italy's game.

I need to make sure I include all these points: the injuries, the substitutions, and the reactions from Wales' coach and Henson. The summary should be concise, highlighting the main key ideas without extra details.
</think>

Wales center Sonny Parker and number eight Ryan Jones will miss Saturday's game with Italy due to injury. Parker has not fully recovered from a neck injury that prevented him from winning against England, while Tom Shanklin is expected to continue at centre. Jones had a collard bone issue when coming on for England, so he joined flanker Colin Charvis (foot injury) on the bench. Mike Ruddock may make Gavin Henson his first-choice kicker in Rome, and Henson is relishing media attention after last Saturday's 11-9 Six Nations win against England, where he had already missed shots at goal. Wales' coach Mike Ruddock highlighted their heroics with Parker scoring a huge late penalty.
tinyllama:1.1b: Wales suffered a double injury blow in their match against Italy by losing center Sonny Parker and flanker Ryan Jones due to injuries. Despite not recovering from his neck injury, center Tom Shanklin is expected to remain in the squad. Kicker Mike Ruddock may also make fly-half Gaivin Henson's kicks more prominent in the upcoming match against Italy. Both players have been struggling with their respective injuries since last weekend's win over England. Despite this, coach Mike Ruddock believes that his team is ready to compete and improve after their performance against Italy. The squad will head to Rome ahead of their next game in the Six Nations Championship on Thursday.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Wales faced a double blow this week as centre Sonny Parker suffered a neck injury that kept him sidelined against Italy. Despite the absence of Parker, number eight Ryan Jones is expected to continue at center. The team will also miss the influence of flanker Colin Charvis due to an injury sustained in the match against England. Mike Ruddock has announced that Gavin Henson will take up the mantle as a first-choice kicker after Stephen Jones handed over responsibility due to Henson's increased kicking range. This decision marks a significant change for Wales, which had been using Henson as its first-choice kicker since the team's 11-9 win over England in the Six Nations. However, Henson may have to give up his role as a key player if selected as Gavin Jones takes up the opportunity to prove himself by taking on the responsibility of kicking first for Wales.

Wales coach Mike Ruddock said he is thrilled with the media attention on Henson but also wants to talk about his kicking range in selection this week. Henson says he enjoys the pressure and that a short preparation period before Italy will be beneficial for the team.

Coach Mike Ruddock may opt for Gavin Henson as Wales' kicker instead of first-choice Stephen Jones, acknowledging Henson's greater kicking range and recent success in penalties. Henson, who was instrumental in Wales' 11-9 victory over England with crucial late field goals, is reportedly enjoying the increased media attention since the game. The team will depart for Rome on Thursday, just a few days before their next match against Italy.
